description:
If you like supporting small local businesses. Give Young's Cafe a shot. It's a small mom & pop's shop. That has been open for more than 40 years! 40 YEARS?!?! The interior can do a little work, but this is your neighborhood hole in the wall spot. I usually come in during lunch time. The mom usually does the servicing. While the dad is the master chef. They do have another waitress that comes in after 3pm. I perfer the Mom though. They hand make their own appetizers and the tasty chili sauce as well. On a few occasions I would buy a mason jar of chili sauce for the house. I have a handful of dishes I like here.

- Pan Fried Noodles (crunchy small egg noodles with choice of meat/vegetables/gravy on top)
- Chicken or Cod Fish Salt & Pepper
- Wonton Soup (broth is really clear and they make it themselves)
- Curry Chicken Basil Chow Fun or Fried Rice
- Eggrolls or Potstickers

There's plenty more. 

I like how you can also replace the white rice with fried rice/chow mein/brown rice for an extra charge.

If your rice plate don't have vegetables. You can add broccoli/chinese broccoli/mixed vegetable for an extra charge as well.

They have a REALLY good selection of sodas/beers.
I never walked into a chinese restaurant that has IPA/Stella/Blue Moon. Of course they have Tsing Tao/Heineken as well. 

Give this place a shot. You won't regret it!
author: A M.

description:
Just ordered the Won ton soup. Even for that, there was confusion about which one. Didn't realize there were two on the menu. "One is 'Won Ton', one is 'Special Won Ton...' OK...

Certainly nothing special about the regular one. Salty, hard to eat. No meat. Maybe I'll try the other one. 

The place has a smell of milder or old rags.
author: Phil J.

description:
The place was very uncrowded when I went for lunch, and apparently they have some seating upstairs but the few tables downstairs were mostly empty while I was there (I think there might have been one other person).

I had the Kung Pao Chicken here, and it was a little bit disappointing. There was both a lack of flavor and lack of good ingredients in the dish. I kind of wish there was more to it besides me feeling it was bland and one-dimensional.

I also ordered a lemon coke, and I guess that just means its a coke with a bunch of lemon slices in it...
author: Tyler T.

description: When their walnuts shrimp meal pal comes up, I can't help but get it. They always give plenty of rice - thank goodness because I eat 2 bowls in one sitting. Rice has nice fragrant smell. It's a small hole in the wall. It's good. Friendly service.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Roast Duck Wonton Soup is great! 

If you're a tourist from Des Moines and are turned off by the ambiance I get it, move on but know this is the real deal! This is a dive.

Simple, fast home cooking! (I don't really know what that means but I'd like to think this is it.)

Get the Roast Duck Wonton Soup!
Get the Char Siu Gai Lan Fried noodle. Very fresh!

Get what ever it's all good!

I come here once a month!
author: Justin S.

description: Fast and OK food at this hole in the wall. The sesame beef was good. I rate Henry's Hunan better.
author: Sunil R.

description: Well, we gave it a shot because of the last rating, however, the service was not friendly at all.  There was a table sat before ours and they can't decide what they wanted to order and the waitress said we can't order first since it would mess up her system......  WHAT!?  But I have to say their dishes are okay.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I wish Young's Cafe would get more love because they really deserve it. The restaurant is mostly ran by a married couple. The husband is the chef and the wife does pretty much everything else when they do not have help. 

I have been to this mom & pop's place several times and I have truly never been disappointed. The flavor is always there. One of my favorite dishes to order is the curry fried rice; it comes with some basil and sliced tomatoes stir fried with rice in a curry powder. I also love their sauteed string beans. When we ordered the sauteed string beans, it was stir fried with mixed with some crispy pork. The chef also recommended a soy-sauce dipped chicken that was not on the menu but
 it was delicious! He explains that the marinate is not pure soy sauce but a special mix which he calls "thai-yea" chicken.

I've also tried their regular beef pho which has a very clear and fresh tasting broth for anyone who is interest. I definitely recommend supporting this local restaurant. The business owners are super friendly, the food is affordable and the food is what you will call authentic Chinese food!
author: Linda H.

description: This place literally is terrible. The quality of the food is disappointing. The rice is cheap & one of the cheapest grains I ever had in Chinatown.... the chicken was not fresh and barely any meat with my meal. Like seriously? I get more food at Panda Express for the price and it taste better. And 45 minutes later, my tummy was not happy... no restroom trip required but...the food made it hurt and I didn't have anything else after lunch.. Nice staff though...just not good food.
author: Ann L.

description:
As a Chinese nation, this is the most terrible Chinese restaurant I have ever tried in San Francisco. I ordered a dish named black pepper beef. It looked terrible and tasted terrible as well! Too salty!! The chef put too much salt inside, I couldn't bear. I talked this to the waitress, a Chinese lady who speaks Cantonese. She looked offended and upset. She argued: "怎么可能会咸呢？不可能！我们这儿这么多客人都没说过咸！"（"How come? No way it's too salty! No customer here complained it's salty ever!") She even used a fork to try this dish by herself (with my permission), then still insisted that it's good, not salty at all. I took it as an indication that it was my problem, not theirs. 

I had to order another dish, orange chicken, hoping to have better luck this time. (I didn't walked away to try a different restaurant because it took me more than 5 minutes to find a parking lot along the street, i don't wanted to waste that effort and do the search again.) I also ordered a bowl of steamed rice, in case the taste of the second dish is heavy too. Fortunately, the orange chicken tasted OK. But I finally paid more than double as I expected, with the black pepper beef almost untouched. 

When I paid the bill, the waitress said sorry to me. She explained that she was not the boss of the restaurant,and therefore couldn't do much for me. I'm not angry with her emotionally. But still, a very disappointing experience at this restaurant. I won't recommend it to any of my friends at San Francisco.
author: Dapeng L.

description:
lunch special w/ rice & soup of the day - written out on white board; anything you can choose from for less than $10.

Excellent Chinese Food in downtown with the most affordable price.

Parking can be difficult so be wary :) 

This premise has been here forever but quality stays the same since the first time i tried them in the 90's
author: Dedy G.

description:
Mediocrity is the perfect word I think when I see this... As much as it pains me.

R&G is packed full of Asian... Here I am staring at single Caucasian regular.  Even with that said

Pot stickers was the smallest I have ever seen and bland.
Seafood had a smell aroma... Just hoping I don't spend tonight on the throne.

$25 dissatisfied
author: David H.

description:
Tucked away in a corner sits a somewhat typical Chinatown cafe.  Across the street begin the skyscrapers of the Financial District.  Yelpers say that Young's Cafe gets busy during lunch, and due to its prime location, I believe it.

For its price, I'm surprised that it's a clean, well-done-up little restaurant.  I did not go downstairs, but there are plenty of signs saying that there's more room to sit down there.  My main thought:  A good place for a date, if your love doesn't insist on the Tadich Grill.

I got spicy garlic chicken to go.  Lots of little chunks of chicken, and it was spicy indeed.  The garlic sauce was the highlight of the meal;  unfortunately, the chicken was almost tasteless.  Also came with soup and broccoli, I ate neither.

Good place if you just need to pick up some cheap Chinese lunch quickly and don't need a high-quality taste.  I rushed in and rushed out, didn't look at much of the rest of the menu, so if you do have a date here, I hope that your food is as nice as the atmosphere.  Because, in this case, it wasn't.  I may want to try it again, though, with my family along.
author: Ron L.

description:
Fast...attentive....

First time back in 4 years.   Still the same...great  flavor, good service and reasonably clean for Chinatown. 

I suggest eating downstairs, cooler and more room to stretch.
author: Jerry W.

description: Barely edible.  The soup was a gel.  The honey walnut shrimp was covered in a thick mayonaise smelling paste
author: Rob L.

description: Delicious. Clean. I exercised retrains and did not order the Peking Duck. I'll be back for that dish. I ordered the sea food rice. It was not over salted and in context seemed healthy. The seafood was fresh and cooked perfectly. All dishes are very affordable.
author: Robert B.

description: My wife used to eat here all the time and loved it, so she wanted me to try it today while we were visiting San Francisco. This place is amazing! I got the special, sesame beef. They brought out the soup it came with, a thick chicken soup, it was soooo good. The sesame beef had a sublime sauce and the beef was deep fried perfectly. It had that toasty after taste that great fried food should have. I've lived in the Bay Area for 26 years. I've also spent a lot of time if NYC and Toronto. This is among the best Chinese food I've ever had.
author: Joe J.

description:
Yay, pan fried noodles cooked served fast (less than 10 mins)! The pan fried noodles aren't on the menu, but they're available with any of the noodle dishes upon request. I usually order it with chicken and mixed veggies.

Yay, free house soup! 

Yay, $7 lunch specials! 

Yay, they accept credit card! 

Yay, I'd come back!
author: Audrey L.

description:
Cheap, fast, yummy food, and friendly service! I advise ordering family style and sharing.

Their hot and sour soup is my favorite, but their sautéed string beans come in as a close second. The dishes are flavorful but are also more on the salty end, so have your rice and tea ready! I've only been here for dinner, but I've heard their lunch specials are the better deals. Hope to check that out one of these days!

Their restroom, and more tables, are located downstairs which is a bit odd, but guess it makes sense since space is so limited in the city. Parking may also be a bit difficult. Call in beforehand for takeout!
author: Kristi T.

description: I was looking for some place quick to eat before meeting some people. I ordered the salt and peppered wings which were very good but I thought took longer than they should as it did not appear that busy (I will temper that observance in that I was upstairs so I don't know how full the downstairs was). If I am in San Francisco again I would like to try more of the offerings.
author: Ed F.

description: This was a quick place that we find at the corner.  When entered , the entrance was a bit to cramp. We were put on to the corner by the door way. The workers seems a bit nosey. I ordered tofu. I wasn't expecting it to be deep fried. It was good though the salt and maybe msg is overwhelming on the top.  I need to gulp down water to get the taste off my tongue. I never had this kind of tofu before it was airey and crisp.
author: Anonymous U.

description:
Egg rolls = good. (Noodles and vegetables, no meat inside. No, NO MEAT.)

Fried wontons = good.  (It's a crispy, almost-flat wonton with a bit of pork filling inside. Trust me, it's good, especially with their sweet and sour sauce.)

My friend said he enjoyed his beef noodle dish.  I'll need to come back and try more. :)

Prices = reasonable. 
 
Service = curt but friendly. 

Seating = they've got enough for a decent crowd. A few 6-tops, 4-tops and a couple of big round tables.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This place is cheap, fast, and darn good. I ordered an off-menu item: beef with asparagus over pan fried HK-style noodles. It was delicious, came with free soup, and was served with a smile.

I will be back... likely tonight. Oops.
author: Meredith S.

description:
We were expecting some really great Chinese food going here, but it ended up being pretty basic.  

The portions were small, but the prices matched.  My Diet Coke was served to me in a can!  No soy sauce on the table.  The food was lacking flavor.  

Our waitress was kind and attentive. 

The restroom was downstairs, which was an interesting trip, my friend reported.  The ground floor where we were seated holds 4 tables, but he said that downstairs there were many more tables.  He said the restroom was clean.

We were the only ones there on a Thursday night till someone came in just before we left.

The ambiance needs some help.  Nothing bad, just quite plain with faded signs and pictures taped to the wall.

Food: 2
Service: 4
Ambiance: 3
Parking: 0 - No street parking available; had to park a few blocks away
author: Sheri C.

description: Great place for a fast and delicious lunch.  Large menu, good and fast service.  Perfect to start a long day of walking through the city.  Will come again.
author: Maria V.

description:
This place is cheap, good, fast, and friendly. They give you a free soup when you sit with water and tea. I've tried a few things on the menu and you really can't go wrong. Especially when you have a hour lunch they will get you in and out to accommodate you. 
They have a variety of lunch specials and the prices are very reasonable. i would recommend coming here if you are craving some good Chinese food.
author: Irma R.

description: Have been going to this place since I could remember. My dad found this place back in 1984 when he was working in the city and has been going back ever since. We always get our same meals: tomato beef over pan fried noodles, chicken & bok choy over pan fried noodles, Mongolian beef over pan fried noodles, spicy garlic chicken over pan fried noodles, hot and sour soup, and potstickers. Never had a bad meal! The only thing that has changed is the people and the portion size is a little smaller. They know us when we walk in the door!
author: Karen B.

description:
I'm a food snob! An over the top stereotypical food snob, I even have an imaginary checklist that i would mark off every time i see something i did not like, but today was different. We were walking toward R&G lounge and we saw the line out the door so we just went to the first place we saw. I didn't even check yelp for the ratings until after i ordered. 

I guess when people see a 3 star restaurant - its a toss up if they will go or not. Everyone wants to go to the highest rated place or the trendiest, but in reality yelp is 80% filled with 3 star restaurants. So this time i decided not to be a food snob, but a normal person who just wants to eat. 

We sat down, the staff were extremely nice and polite and the food was cheap. Even tho it was cheap, the food tasted good. I guess my expectation for a 3 star restaurant is low, so i was pleasantly pleased. The food was fresh and not reheated and portions were just right. 

I think a lot of us overlook the 3 star restaurants and only go toward the 4+ stars even tho most of those places are over rated and all hype. i should make a yelp challenge to check out a 3star place that has less than 10 reviews. It was always a dream of mine to make a small time restaurant popular because someone read my review.
author: Ryan R.

description: I have visited this location for lunch in multiple occasions and needless to say, I am always satisfied. The place is a little cramped, but if you're from the city, that shouldn't be too big an issue. The staff is quick to seat you and take your order. The food itself takes a little bit but nothing worth fussing about. Whether you're by yourself or a party of 6, I find this place to be a great location for some great multicultural Asian cuisine. I ordered a bowl of the won ton soup with the Orange chicken lunch special. Not only was it enough food, it was all under $15. The portion of the Orange chicken was what I expected while the bowl was more than enough! Courteous staff and decent environment. If you're looking for quick and tasty Asian cuisine while touring Chinatown or on break from work, I recommend this place. I'll be returning next time I'm in the city.
author: Carlo F.

description:
2.5 stars.
This economic boom has ruined my old food options.
Portions seem to be smaller and prices higher.  I used to frequent Young's Cafe back in the day when I worked in FiDi.  I was recently in the area and hungry so I decided to order my old favorite... salt and pepper fish.  The batter is this "puffy" batter, not like the breading I'm used to.  And the portions sizes are smaller.  It still is tasty, but this is no longer my first choice for salt and pepper fish.  Nostalgic for the old days when I could go to certain places for certain dishes...
author: Angelique B.

description:
Prices are low but portions are a bit small. Food has good Chinese taste.

Service was faster than most Chinese restaurants. A clean bathroom. Was able to watch the chef prepare our food, from a dining room window to the kitchen.

Fried rice: Good taste  4.0 star

Beef chow fun. Average  3.0 star

wet (gravy) beef pan fried noodles.  Very good. 4.5 stars'

Egg roll.  Order was too small 

So many great Chinese restaurants nearby. This one is also good. 

Takes Visa/Mastercard but not Discover.
author: Steven G.

description:
This is a convenient spot to grab a quick lunch. The decor leaves something to be desired, but the staff makes up for that with their friendly and welcoming attitude. You also can see the chef go at it in the kitchen!

Food:
Lunch Special: Spicy Fried Chicken w/ Fried Rice: 8/10
Awesomeness

Lunch Special: String Beans w/ Minced Pork: 6/10
This dish is usually too salty, but it's pretty tasty.

Young's Fried Rice: 4/10
I like the simple fried rice served on the side, but I don't like the fried rice here when it has a bunch of other ingredients. My uncle owns his own restaurant and makes the best fried rice, chow mein, egg rolls, Chinese fried chicken, etc. I've ever had. I virtually always try these dishes at other Chinese restaurants, but it's just never as good. The closest I've had is the combination fried rice at May Flower Berkeley.

Egg rolls: 6/10
He hand makes these himself and they're pretty good, but I'm not a fan of the filling he uses.

Honey Walnut Prawns: 6/10
Pretty solid dish, but I've had better.

Sweet and Sour Pork: 4/10
This is normally one of my favorite dishes at some restaurants, but it wasn't that good here unfortunately.

BBQ Pork Chow Mein: 6/10
Solid chow mein.
author: John D.

description: There are very few places that truly deserve a one-star review, but young's cafe is one of them. The service is non-existent and owners are incredibly rude. Avoid this place!
author: Sally C.

description: Excellent food, very good service and reasonable prices. Tiny restrooms and decor was a bit dated, but I would definitely come back.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Disappointing. I was the only customer but I was shoved in a corner because I had a suitcase with me. 

They got my order wrong, but my blood sugar was too low to argue. I ordered Chicken Eggplant with Basil and got Chicken with Basil and jalapeño and red pepper flakes. Good thing I like spicy food. It was served over a bed of shredded lettuce to make it look like the portion was bigger and it was impossible to extricate the chicken but leave the lettuce behind. It was flavorful, just not what I wanted/expected.

I had to order a side of rice separately--for an additional $1.50. (The lunch special comes with rice and soup.) 

Service was solicitous and what I would expect when I am awkwardly the only customer in the restaurant. 

I hadn't wanted to walk another 8 minutes with my suitcase to go to the other place on my list, but now I'm wishing I had.
author: Restles S.

description: I've been eating at Young's since 1983.  They have a dish "Beef in Chinese Style" over rice, but I always get it over "crispy noodles."  It's kind of a sweet and sour red sauce with lots of onions and green peas.  It's really really good.
author: Paul B.

description:
Our original pick for dinner was R&G lounge but it had more than 1 hr wait, so we walked into this place just to grab some bites before everything closed up in the area.

Food was just mediocre, nothing would draw us back again. Then they automatically add 20% tip to our bill (only 3 ppl sitting at a small table) - not sure if this is a norm in the SF Chinatown area. Just be aware.
author: YP F.

description: I never tried Pho so I ordered the Shrimp Pho. It was alright, but my friend's ordered truly good stuff. Young's chow mien was great, and the Mongolian beef was greeeeat.
author: Katie F.

description:
+1 star for the price!

Working in the FiDi you can't really find cheap decent food around. But this place is cheap and pretty good. They take cards, but beware they frown upon charging anything less than $10. Food is cheap and fast and decent everything you want for lunchtime!

Dried Fried Beef Chow Fun for $7.25 comes with soup, can't beat that price here in the FiDi.
author: Julian T.

description:
Fast, efficient, somewhat reasonably priced Chinese food.

Definitely has the "guai lo" flavor to my Mongolian beef. It was definitely spicy enough, but there was a distinct sweet flavor the "guai lo" crave. It brought about images of walnut shrimp, kung pao chicken, and Panda Express to mind.

The waiter and the service was really nice and FAST.
author: Doug R.

description:
If I could give a ZERO star, I would definitely do that!!!

Felt like I was treated differently than other customers in the store, ok well, not felt like, I WAS treated differently! 

When I got in the store, the female staff asked me what I'd like to order. Ok so I was answering her, but was being cut off- I hadn't even finished my sentence! She said: Hold on! They need to order! She pointed to the other table and walked away quickly. I'd been standing in front of the counter for about ten minutes and was not even being served! After ten minutes, she finally asked me what I'd like to order, so I kept waiting for my meal. Suddenly she talked to me, but I couldn't even understand because of her accent. I replied to her, saying "What?". She then shouted at me, saying: "Give me money! Give me money!" After giving her the money, she THREW (Yes! Threw! You read it right!) my change on the table and walked away without saying a word. 

It was very very rude! The worst service I've ever had! It made me feel like she didn't want to serve "Asians" customers. When I was at the store, all the customers, except me, were all Americans. The lady was being so nice to them, speaking softly to them, and always smiling at them. I didn't show any poor attitude, so I really don't get it why I was treated this way! 

HORRIBLE service! VERY RUDE and DISRESPECTFUL! Will NEVER ever go there again and will NOT recommend to any of my friends!
author: Victoria H.

description:
Teeny tiny place, food cooked to order. Got a special off the board, sesame chicken. I've never had such crispy chicken covered in a sweet glazey sauce in my life. I'm used to getting soggy meat. So this place is a def plus for making the food so fresh!! 
No thrills, no fuss. Just quick, fresh, good Chinese food and decent prices.
author: Sarah U.

description:
I paid over $18 dollars and got 5 peices of shrimp mixed with mayo over a plate of white rice which was supposed to be honey walnut over rice. I received 5 prices of shrimp for $12 dollars and scoops of rice for $6

I will never order lunch here again and the sad thing is if they would have given at least what I payed for I would have been a returning customer due to my employment being across the street.

Unfortunately my first experience eating here is the worst
author: Dazy A.

description:
Sometimes, it's difficult to write a review for a place like this, as it's not easy to categorize it. I guess the best way to describe it, would be to compare it to both a Chinese restaurant, a takeaway and a snack bar. I guess it is a good place if you have a busy day and you need a quick fix for lunch just as I did when I walked in. 

I tried their cashew chicken, which wasn't the best I ever had, but still it was quite good and, as I stated before, if you really need to finish that project you're working on, quality is a nice plus, but you really want to have a meal that's ready in under 10 minutes, gets you going for the next hours and preferably isn't too unhealthy, and that is exactly what this place does: getting you a quick, solid meal in under 10 minutes which still tastes quite good. The prices are definitely ok. 

Seen the situation I was in, this place would have gotten 4 stars, but the service could have been better. They were friendly, but it still felt cold and to the point, as opposed to what I have been used to ever since I arrived in San Francisco. 

I sure will go back, and I really recommend this place to anyone who needs what I needed at that time or just walks into Chinatown and needs a decent meal for a good price. Don't force yourself to make the detour if you are really looking to experience the best Chinese cuisine San Francisco has to offer though, as there are better places around if you have some spare time.
author: Nicolas S.

description:
Food is fresh & servers friendly. 
Why the 1 star then?? 
I ordered my food to go. I specifically said no mushrooms as I'm allergic! When I was 1/2 way through my sizzling rice soup (which for some reason had no rice, btw) I found a mushroom!! Great! 
So, now, as I'm waiting for my ride to leave work early & lose pay to go to the doctor, I figured I'd write my review before I get too sick. Thanks a lot Young's! Maybe next time when someone says they have an allergy, you'll pay attention!! Between the loss of pay & the drs bill, this was the most expensive & disappointing soup ever!
author: Laura B.

description: What a failure of a restaurant. Run, don't walk away from the salt/pepper cod ... more breading than actual cod and some of the breading was under-cooked. I hate it when restaurants make cuts when you're okay paying for quality ... add a couple bucks to the price and make your food less shi++y.
author: Vivek D.

description:
In Chinatown, mostly every restaurant is fast, cheap, tasty. Add this one to the list. 

The original restaurant we had wanted to go to for a quick dinner was closed. Not wanting to pay for a $40 for a crab at R&G Lounge (I think Thanh Long's crabs are better) we eat at the first Chinese restaurant we see. Plus R&G seems way busier since their spot on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations. 
  
All the typical Chinese-American dishes on the menu but not wanting to fuss on what to order we do the $10.50 per person dinner combo. 

Egg flour soup - just right
Fried won ton http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/tfd48TNXjT05buDGg-ZtcQ/l   -- nice and crispy, the filling was burnt inside. 
House special fried rice http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/vcCd-Ad9YAR-haO9tN8Qbw/l -- perfect
Sweet n sour pork - ok
Cashew chicken http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/G_9qouZc6hEFvxVpj9lang/l -- the best tasting item
Beef with white fried noodles http://static3.px.yelp.com/bphoto/uLdiFU_4OwV4qiLYjuNKKw/l  
 

Not the tastiest nor the worst but it's inexpensive and lives up to the stereotypical Chinese hole in the wall.
author: Earl G.

description: I was taken hear by my date. She has been many times. It was raining and we needed a break. The staff was very friendly. Tea was served quick. Then our rice and main dish. Everything was hot and fresh looking. The restaurant was very clean. My girlfriend and I each had one of there clay pot dishes. I had BBQ pork with oysters. Great flavor. I will be back.
author: Corey P.

description: Yummy food, friendly service and reasonable prices. I usually spend $8 for a rice plate with soup. Very satisfying food and very fast service. I go there twice a week.
author: Shane T.

description: Walking in you know what to expect. Inexpensive. Small portions. Solid for lunch. Fast.
author: Brennan D.

description:
"My fellow Americans...
You should feel grateful to live in a country where you can deep fry anything. Life is hard enough when the right to encrust a pork chop with oily breadiness is taken away from you. But aside from the current administration, I am proud to live in a nation where I can eat a deep-fried pork chop. I'm Hillary Rodham Clinton, and I approve of this message...except for my husband who really needs to lay off this stuff."

Hillary may as well talk about pork chops since she can't seem to make herself appetizing to superdelegates on the fence. But for $6.75, I did order the deep-fried pork chop lunch special and it was seasoned with salt, pepper and all sorts of hot peppers and scallions (see my photo). Tasty except when it repeated on me back at work. It comes with a heaping scoop of rice, a nice little cup of egg drop soup, and a plastic tumbler of warm tea.

It's that small place on the corner you see when you're barreling down Kearny on the way to North Beach. I get there a little later than the standard lunch hour to avoid the rush, and it seems to work for me. I also think they are among the friendliest Chinatown eateries, perhaps because it's located on the fringe and caters to the persnickety white-collar drones. Who knows...but Bubba seems to like it. Isn't that right, Hil?

FOOD - 3 stars...rib-sticking Chinese food, no complaints on the portions
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...pretty typical...who makes all those pink tablecloths?...must be filthy rich
SERVICE - 3.5 stars....pretty darn friendly
TOTAL - 3 stars...worth a lunch stop now and then, but watch your cholesterol levels
author: Ed U.

description: This place was pretty good. Been here twice. The walnut prawn dish and Mongolian beef were pretty tasty and decent price for lunch menu.
author: Frank T.

description:
Came to Young's with a large work crowd and we ordered about 9 dishes covering the protein and veggie gamut pretty much. 

There wasn't one thing set down in front of me that I didn't enjoy with my favorite being the Mongolian Beef that had a nice heat level complimenting a savory, barely sweet, brown sauce. Overall would have liked to have tried more spicy dishes but, being along for the ride, I rolled with what came my way.  Second favorite were the honey/walnut prawns.  Not sure what they do to those little things but, yum... 

While Young's was delish, I imagine there may be even better Chinese cuisine to be had in San Francisco and I would welcome any suggestions for the next visit!
author: Tom C.

description:
Great food and service. The only place that will make Mu Shu pork and a side order of garlic sauce without question.

Great family-run restaurant.
author: Bus Driver I.

description:
Matt and his 3 colleagues including one of his "PUNK-ASS" boss landed here for lunch and a brief meeting. We were here a little before noon, which the lunch crowd started to piled in, moments later. Parking around this small corner Chinese restaurant wasn't bad; because we can park anywhere we want. 

The four of us ordered the lunch specials, which also included a bowl of complimentary house soup. After one sip of the free soup, we all bypassed the salty soup and waited for the real food, our lunch plates.

Matt ordered the General Chicken over rice plate for $6.00. Matt's plate was a good size portion, but tasted "just" ok. Matt's boss had dry beef chow-fun, which was greasy, but flavorful, and the other 2 buttheads ordered the Chicken and Bok-Choy over deep-fried noodles and Beef-stew and tofu over rice, which both of the plates turns our to be the best opposed to Matt and boss.

We were seated downstairs. We were done by 12:30 and as soon as we went upstairs to pay our bill, working people from the neighboring area were standing and waited to be seated. This corner restaurant must be a popular place during lunchtime.
author: Matt G.

description:
I just realized that I need to review Young's.  I've been coming here for more years than I'd like to admit.  They're dependable.  I like dependable.  The food is just fine.  No, it's not Gary Danko or R&G Lounge, but the servings are large, and they have a good variety of stuff.  The staff is always efficient and friendly.   The cook is friendly.  Poke your head in that little opening between the upstairs dining room and the kitchen and say howdy.  He'll appreciate it.

Oh--did I mention cheap?  Really, really cheap.  That allows me to forgive a lot.

When I go, I tend to go at off-hours because I hate crowds.  The fact that there *are* crowds here, year in, year out, should tell you something.  

It's fast, it's not fancy, but it's good and dependable, and I like it.
author: Earline A.

description: Trust me, just don't go here. It's the worst restaurant in Chinatown. Spend your money elsewhere.
author: James L.

description: Very good!  I ate the prawn with cashew nuts. I wasn't too thrilled about Nickelback on the radio, but I didn't let that affect my rating.
author: John L.

description:
I rarely pick Chinese food when I eat out because I grew up on it (being Chinese and all) 

but when I do this is one of the few I'd actually seek out. relative cheap and hits the spot. staff is friendly

note: I only go here during the non-peak hours; I wouldn't want to get seated downstairs either..ventured down once when i needed to use the restroom..let's just say I've learned not to sip too much tea
author: Whitne Y.

description: Had mixed experiences here. First time I came my Beef Chow Fun was very filling and satisfying. Next time I brought my co-workers and the Beef Chow Fun was without any meat. Probably won't be back here considering R&G is on the same block and is much more consistent.
author: Nelson C.

description: My custom, off menu dish: vegetable chow mien, Hong Kong style (crispy noodles), with black bean sauce, using minimal oil. Ummm, great and healthy. I have eaten here for many years, certainly 10's of times. Cheap, clean enough, reliable, very good (but not great). Thankfully, not the all-too-common cornstarch and grease experience. They do a good job for both tourists and locals, will guide you and customize if you ask. Good attitudes from staff. Community seating at peak lunch time, though they do have a 2nd dining room downstairs in the dungeon.
author: Dick B.

description: Ok food at a cheap price. But, dirty facility. Discussing bathrooms. Slow, unfriendly service.  Only an 86 on the last health inspection, which should be enough reason to avoid.
author: Ohhh Y.

description: Visiting San Francisco for the weekend, was close to china town and decided to give this place a go. Three and a half stars seems high considering the food looked like it came from a can. The only good thing there that came out of a can was a diet coke. Assuming you don't speak Chinese, it's hard to order and understand. We asked for a lemon and straw 3-5 times and never received it. The bill was a little pricey for canned chicken and rice.
author: Kristin M.

description: I had some tasty spicy garlic chicken at this Chinese diner in the Financial District. Apparently everyone leaves this part of town at night and it's more of a lunch spot. The service was attentive, as you might expect at a small family-run restaurant. Will return when I'm back in town.
author: Roy C.

description: Mom from out of town -- where they have one Chinese restaurant -- of course, wanted Chinese food as we were shopping in Chinatown. Did a quick search on Yelp and found one a block away from where we were, Young's Cafe. (Dear Jesus, my mom at 82 and barely mobile was happy to hear about the short walk.) We were all fairly satisfied with our luncheon specials (good until 2:30), quite edible, but unmemorable. That being said, I would go back again to make sure I order what the guy sitting next to me was having! I might have given it a four instead of a three. Sigh, such is the roll of the dice.
author: Albert K.

description:
Nice service.

Mediocre food.
Expensive for small portions.
author: Brett M.

description: Good food, good price, and good service. What else can you ask for more? Lunch here everyday!!! Never disappointed. Eat here lunch every weekday for more than 2 months. They even customize for the dish for us since we like our dish spicy. More than happy to come here again and again before my work is done in sf. Thanks young's cafe.
author: Kaung P.

description: Tried to get dinner at a fancy nearby restaurant -- left after 1.5 hours with a wallet $76 lighter and no dinner.  Stopped in for take away veggie fried rice right at closing time.  Served up with smiles.  Light, hot, not greasy.  Thanks!
author: T. Lee S.

description:
Best damn Chinese food I've found in the city after living here for 7 years. It's an open kitchen so you can watch them prepare your meal and all the fresh meats & veggies are on display. You can't beat the lunch specials for the price and I've not yet once been disappointed with a meal.

My favorite dishes are: Szechuan lamb, honey walnut prawns, spicy basil chicken (double down on this one!), ground pork with string beans.... again, alllll fantastic choices. Damn good food.
author: Brad J.

description: Can't say one bad thing about this place. You walk in and sit down and they bring out the soup of the day either a hot and sour or egg drop. Both are awsome. But then you pick from there menu and you really can't go wrong with anything you get ,there all good. But I'm a fan of the spicy garlic sauce chicken over rice. I would say the best thing on the menu. But since getting another job out side of the city, I can't eat it all the time but when I do go back I always stop and fill my fix.
author: Jacob T.

description:
My friend who eats at Young's 200+ times / year for lunch told me about this place, and I was looking for quick Chinese whole in the wall for my lunch option so I gave it a try.

They have good variety of lunch special.  (Menu http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/screenmenu.asp?restaurantId=8422&htmllink=B96A817415C57BFC2C1F028B0E7B37369363CE1A45277B1EAD4FCA03915300E56A2C482910E5A6A5&taglineid=0 ) 

I was excited when I tasted their soup which comes with the lunch specials.  I usually do not eat free lunch soups.  A lot of times, they are watery and taste less (for example Capital Restaurant  http://www.yelp.com/biz/capital-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:CCQAecGQADc4UI-U074UrQ/query:capital ' s lunch soup is uneatable)

I liked most of their lunch special choices such as:

- Wonton Shrimp Noodle Soup (thin egg noodles not on the menu $7)
-  Scallop & Shrimp with Broccoli(Only thing is there are only 3 Shrimps and 3 scallops sliced in half) 
-  Deep Fried Flounder Fillet with spicy salt
- Cod with Green Beans
-  Prawns with honey walnut
 

* It is a good idea to tell them "Not too much gravy"
author: Chie J.

description:
The base lunch specials are now $6.50 per dish, portions still tiny.  I had a quick lunch with my dad today - I ordered salt & pepper pork chops (six strips of meat) over rice and dad ordered oyster sauce beef over rice (where's the beef - lots of celery? in oyster beef??).  Food was still tasty restaurant was packed.  No service - I had to ask the waitress several times for the bill and again to settle up.  Don't be in a hurry here...

Also check your bill - they tend to overcharge $...
author: Rich W.

description: Got a new job and the lunch period is thirty minutes.  What do I see?  Young's Cafe.  I order the spicy tofu with rice for $6.95.  Food arrives at my table very quickly.  Mind you, its 2:30 in the afternoon and the lunch hour rush is long gone.  Pretty tasty for low budget, economic crisis, priced food. Its better than a fast food joint for about the same price. The restaurant is small and the decor is strictly low budget.  But who cares?  Not I.
author: Gee M.

description:
Cheapest Chinese food we found so we went in and gave it a shot.
Kung Pao Chicken w/ rice and soup & for $6.75 was good with lots of sauce and chicken, but there was too much celery. 
Orange Chicken had pieces of orange in it. Chicken was not fried and it's no Panda Express, which is a good thing!
Service took awhile. There was only one girl cleaning up and taking orders for 5 tables, but we actually put down tip because she looks like she was working hard. It felt like forever when the food arrived. Restaurant really cramped. Only 7 tables, I think. If they were all filled, people would be touching.

Total for 3 people: $21.78.
author: Cathy N.

description:
We come here for lunch every now and then. 
The waitress pretty much knows us by now.. below is what we do.

walk in, say hi, order 2 Minced beef w/ egg over rice

walk straight downstairs, turn on the lights :) pick a table and wait for our food.

waitress brings over daily soup and tea.. 10 min later our food.

Best minced beef w/ raw egg over rice in the area! Sometimes when it's really cold outside we get the roast duck wonton noodle soup instead.. awesome as well. O and if you don't eat beef, wor egg w/ shrimp over rice is just as good.

excellent food, decent price, big portions. YUM.
author: Catalina C.

description:
I ordered the Law Hon with bean curd, glass noodles, black mushrooms, flat mushrooms and tofu Clay Pot, it was yummy. Enough for two people. Optional: steamed rice.

Advice: try not to order anything that is written on the lunch menu on the wall.   Instead,  get the menu and take a gander. If it sounds exotic,  then it probably is very tastey. It likely is something most Chinese would enjoy too.  Like the Law Hon Clay Pot, you wil have to look for it.
author: Bert K.

description:
WHOLE IN THE WALL CHEAP FREAKN EATS!

SF Chinatown... where to go? overwhelmed by the hundreds of Chinese restaurants? Hesitant to go in and order off a menu only in Chinese? No worries... you definately have to drop in at Young's Cafe. 

Nothing scary, all good eats.

Been here many times during those short work lunch hours. Coworkers and I would resort to this place because it's not busy during lunch time, they're fast to serve your food, and the food is DAMN GOOD. You'd think an empty restaurant my have some bad review. LIES. This place is great. 

I usually go for the Rice plates ($5.50). Tried many of them and liked them all but my usual order is: Beef in Chinese Style over rice OR Mongolian Beef.

Definately a hidden treat in ChinaTown.

Prices = cheap
Ambiance = whole in the wall good cheats spot
Food = Yummy

http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/screenmenu.asp?restaurantId=8422&htmllink=8BDDFBD357C13B7FAA65252D31445680D064DC1C60225D487B8818844AA50057C9541861B222F2C5&taglineid=0
author: Jane A.

description:
Nice place.  the greeting may seem a little aggressive - "FOR TAKE OUT?!!?!?!" but once you settle in its kinda nice.  Its like when you see your sister after a little too long apart, she may come across as over bearing but its only because  she wants to spend time with you.

I had the "sezchuan noodles" for lunch.  nice price, came with soup.  It was spicy (i like that), they made it with no meat for me.  At first i felt it was too much sauce for the noodles, but dang if i did not eat nearly the whole plate.  I looked down and all that was left was a super saucey pile that I couldn't take down.

The atmosphere is nice, people dropping in like family.  One sweet couple was eating together and the old man could not zip his jacket zipper because of  his mittens.  I was so tempted to zip his jacket for him.  His wife (of many years) zipped him up and said, "Okay now?".  OMG - I love that old couple.

Come to young's, try it. If you get the sezchaun noodles, share it with a friend.
author: Jaime O.

description:
Gross Food, Terrible Service

I came in at 11:00 a.m. and ordered honey walnut prawns, which were on the lunch special menu.  I asked if they came with rice and was told "no".  So I added rice and egg rolls.  My total was $21, which I thought was high.  

A minute later I noticed on the lunch special board that it said "comes with rice" and was advertised at $7.50.  When I pointed that out, the cashier said, "You didn't tell me you wanted the lunch portion.  We already starting making it."  (They are not breading egg rolls in the back or boiling rice, they're simply heating the food.  Ridiculous.)  She refused to downsie my order.  Then the food turned out to be terrible, so I threw it out.

When you come in at lunch, the assumption shouldn't be that you want dinner.
When you ask if the item comes with rice and there is a lunch special with rice, the assumption shouldn't be that you couldn't possibly want that.
author: K F.

description: So disappointed.  I ordered the Chicken Won Ton Soup.  They charged me $7.05 for what should have been $5 at the most.  Watery broth, tiny won tons (used to be plumper), slim chicken (used to be big chunks)....they even skimped on bok choy.  They seem to have gotten greedy. I won't go back.  Staff is friendly.  I never sit down here.  The seating is too crowded and dirty.  Where can I get a good bowl of won ton soup in chinatown?  My goodness!
author: Edyn O.

description: My rating is based on the relative excellence of the food, when compared with the price. Young's is a tiny, dingey restaurant on the edge of Chinatown, just one block from the Financial District. English is not the first language of any of the staff, but they are helpful with interpreting the menu.The basics are just fine: pot stickers, won ton soup with barbecued pork, chow fun etc. But they also have some interesting dishes as specials every day. this is a great lunch place!
author: Norman R.

description: Amazing tomato beef pan fried noodles.  The way I like is, without that much sauce, crispy.  I'm astonished by the variety of noodles, rice, dishes that come out of that little kitchen.  Those two guys back there, know their Chinese food.  Lunch here can be crowded as most places around FiDi are at that time.  There is a hidden downstairs eating area that sits another 30 people.  I don't recommend sitting down there as the wait staff will not check up on you.  For quicker service, sit upstairs.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I was craving chinese food today for lunch and since this is close to my work I thought I would try it out. I've always passed by for years but never went in. After reading a few reviews on Yelp I decided "what the hell". So I walked in and ordered food to go.  Having never been there I wanted time to look over the menu, but as soon as I walked in I got a "hi, to go? what are you having"  - Jeez ! I mean give me a little bit of time to decide lady!  

Anyway, I decide to get combination chow mein (crispy noodle) and a side of steamed rice. Took it back to my office to eat in peace. 

Typical chinese food. Nothing extraordinary about the taste. But it filled me up and I spent less than $10.  I'll probably go back.
author: Maribel S.

description:
So I'm moving jobs, and this means that I am moving a whole 2 blocks away from my current corner of Montgomery and California, this is the equivalent to moving to a new country downtown.  I only go about 2 blocks out from my office to eat, it could be three blocks away and I won't touch it...that's just too far.  Mind you I walk up the 10 flights of stairs to my office twice a day...and yet walking 3 blocks is too far for lunch.  Go figure, it's well known that if you visit a friend's "zone" for lunch you're likely to visit a restaurant you didn't know existed until that moment. 

Anyway, lots of the attorneys in my office frequent this particular joint for lunch so today, considering that I would likely never make the 3 plus block trek again, I decided to head on over. Had the chicken with eggplant and basil lunch special. The soup that comes with is pretty plain and I'm not doing a big dance for the tea they bring you, but I left paying $7.05 and I was full.  The chicken wasn't the highest quality but the eggplant was great, the sauce was flavorful and I dont' have a headache so MSG not an issue. 

If you're looking for cheap Chinese and this is in your "zone" then don't hesitate to hit this place up. It's not Henry's but it'll do in a pinch.
author: Claire C.

description:
This is now officially my favorite place for Chow Mein in alllll of San Francisco.  I work just a couple blocks away down on Kearny and I have to plan my weeks out in advance so I can look forward to the days when I get to order some Chow Mein from Youngs.  I have been on a quest since moving to the city 3 years ago, to find some bomb ass chow mein! Unfortunately I had yet to succeed in my quest, until I stumbled upon Young's.  All the other Chow Mein's I had tried were all off on the veggie to noodle ratio or the sauce would be too think or too thick or just too gross.  BUT YOUNGS YOU SAVED ME!!

Youngs lets me order my Chow Mein exactly how I want it.  Shirmp and broccili please.  And yes, only shrimp and broccoli.  SO GOOD I JUST CAN'T STOP EATING IT!!  

and i'm sure everything else on the menu is bomb too.  i can honestly tell you that when I'm in there grindy down on broccoli and shrimp chow mein that i over hear everyone order different things, and ever plate thats carried out of the kitchen looks delish!
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Young's Cafe is perfect for a quick cheap and unassuming Chinese lunch in the FiDi.  

I was pleased with everything from the food, to the price, to the service.  The servers were really nice and didn't seem rushed to get you in and out.  I got the beef chow fun and it came with a soup; both of which were delicious.  My friend got house fried rice and orange chicken which were also pretty good.  

To top it off, we got orange slices with our fortune cookies.  Orange slices! What a decadent surprise!
author: James C.

description:
This restaurant is bigger than it seems. It has more seating downstairs so there are actually more people in here than you think. Good food, cheap, friendly service, quick. I'd definitely go back.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Nice little Chinese takeaway and restaurant up the road from my new office. The lunch specials are pretty amazing, $6.50 gets you a big plate of rice with your choice of chicken, prawns or pork. And you get a bowl of hot and sour soup, although this isn't that great.

I've been there a couple of times already, it has always had a consistent crowd of people waiting to pick up orders and others eating. Nice place for quick and good HK-style Chinese.

My fortune was "Do not dwelll on differences with a loved one. Try to compromise" Well that doesn't make it very fun.
author: Joseph T.

description: Small and cozy, great service, mediocre food, but it is cheap. Not great if you're in a hurry, but fine if you have an hour for lunch.
author: Spenser T.

description:
Portions and quality of foods that we ordered was not great.. we ordered a selection of beef, pork, shrimp, fish, and noodle meals..

Went there with family for Chinese New Year, the waitress gave us House chicken instead of General chicken that we ordered. The Cook all ready made it and waitress served it to us knowlingly and just said the cook forgot , just ahead this is good, eat this OK." Service was poor, no water refils, only when asked.  I ususally am a big tipper depending on food, how well the waitress pays attention to detail, and customer service..

Here's the kicker  after i paid for the bill, the waitrees runs out to the table and looks at the tip,   I'n a loud voice, she said "only three dolla?." Wow, what do you expect from bad service. .
author: Michael B.

description:
I came here randomly with my aunts. The food was SO good. 

I usually eat at the Szechuan Taste on Taraval, but this is a good 2nd choice. 

Eat at this place for some cheap, tasty, greasy, Chinese food!
author: J-nine I.

description:
Crusty like your eyes after waking up from an all-night rave.

It is cheap tho....
author: Isaac L.

description: Quick service and cheap tasty food. Orange and General Tsao's Chicken are delish!
author: Drew F.

description: Cheap, fast, Americanized Chinese food for lunch. You can eat in or take out, but the decor is, well, non existent. Do NOT go downstairs -- it smells like mold + puke. Stay upstairs if you want to dine in. The food itself is actually pretty decent.
author: Su K.

description:
This is one of our staple lunch spot. For around $7, you get soup and some tasty chinese food.  I like their spicy pork with string beans and the beef/basil curry fried rice.

The service is pretty quick and friendly.
author: danny m.

description: About what I expected.  Fast, cheap, tasty, nothing special.  I got the beef chow fun, which was good but gummy, and certainly very well priced at $7.40 (with free soup)
author: Andy G.

description:
i must say that this place is a victim of "the universal rating system" that i've mentioned before and infects many different rating schemes that you see.  where you have a Gary Danko or M. Mina as the 5 star restaurant and the Mickey D's or Popeye Chicken as the 1 star restaurant and where ever you fall in between those extremes is kind of what rating you get.  personally, i don't subscribe to that rating system.  i rate a place more on how it stacks up against your Expections!  or maybe better said: what it's trying to do... what it does versus what peer-group restaurants are doing, for example.  and i think in that category, this place is 5 stars! 

sure, first, it's chinese food... second, no white table clothes. ... no watiers in tuxedo's... no hot hostess in a cocktail dress that's just a little more revealing than your date's... shall i go on.  but none of these short-comings should prevent it from getting a 5 star rating because it's not trying for any of that nor would any reasonable person expect that stuff from a corner chinese local spot.  

these place gives you free soup when you walk in.  hello!  free soup.  lovin it so far.  they take custom orders.  sweet.  i don't even look at the menu, it's so confusing.  i just tell them what i want.  yeah know... "um, can you do some chicken and brocolli with rice and make it a little spicy?"  they just nod and don't even bother to say: "hey that's not on the menu."  they just write it down and give it to you when they are done with it.  i don't even think they KNOW that what youv'e just ordered isn't on the menu.  i mean, it's not like the menu has special names: reading the menu is like this: 

- beef with asparagus and noodles.
- pork with mixed vegetable and rice.... 

etc... so you can pretty much order whatever you want and they write it down and give it to you.  plus free tea!  sweet!  and free cookies and oranges at the end.  ok, ok.  i know most chinese places give you all that stuff too. yes, this place is kinda liberal with the oil and therefore greasy but hey, comes with the territory.  never has let me down so far.  even people that would have never walked in this place had i not taken them here say that it was pretty good. so there ya go...
author: dan h.

description: I love cheapo Chinese food and this place was great. We came here by accident after our original destination was blocked by the Chinese New Year parade and were very surprised by how good the grubbage was. We sat downstairs with two children (4 and 1) and it was quiet and pleasant to eat in. The service was fast too. However, I also give this place 4 stars because the food is very Americanized and greasy and probably fatty (not for sure), and I LOVE that in my Chinese food!
author: Greg G.

description:
I was craving Chinese food today and didn't take the time to do a Yelp search.  Big mistake.  I set out from my office and popped into the first chinese place I saw.  Second big mistake.  It looked like a good value - entre plus rice plus soup for $6.50.  I ordered the Orange Chicken.  They don't take credit cards (all I had on me) for orders under $10 so I threw in an order of spring rolls.

The chicken was the strangest thing - dry and did not taste like orange at all, though it was colored a vibrant orange.  It tasted sickly sweet, like it was cooked with vanilla soda.  Served over rice - dry boring white rice. No sauce.  The spring rolls had to have been several days old - also dry, totally uninspiring.  Finally - to seal the deal as one of the worst meals I've had - 2 long black hairs in my rice.   ewwwww!
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Hole in the wall Chinese food for lunch on a work day? Who would object to that, right? Right.

So a friend and I go to Young's Café because we were both craving Chinese food, had already planned to eat Chinese food for lunch, and it was fairly close to work. We got there at about 12:30 PM and on a Thursday, we still beat the rush--that is, if they get much of a rush. Young's Café is a pretty small restaurant with probably 8 tables and a maximum occupancy of 30 people (I have no idea why I remember seeing that sign). They give you tea instead of water and they have a lot of lunch specials. We got orange chicken over rice and mongolian beef over rice. The specials also come with soup, which isn't bad. Remember how I said hole in the wall? Well, our food came in like 2 minutes--no joke. I was kind of nervous to eat it. Back to the food. Now I'm really no expert per se in the mongolian beef category, but I'm pretty sure it isn't drenched in sauce--DRENCHED. I was really excited for my mongolian beef, and was pretty disappointed when I got it. Let me clarify, I'm not a super saucey person. I don't like things like teriyaki chicken (unless it's REALLY good). So unless you really like saucey stuff, Young's Café is not for you. The orange chicken wasn't bad. Good thing I was really hungry, otherwise, I probably wouldn't have eaten as much as I had.

The stars are really for speed and location, and maybe just a quarter of a star for the orange chicken.
author: Maureen B.

description: Pretty good food.  I enjoyed my Roast Duck Noodle Soup.  What I didn't like was how my lunch took forever to arrive.  We waited 45 minutes for the appetizer of pot stickers to come out...!!  Everyone in the place arrived after us, but got their food before us.  Was it because we ordered an appetizer?  Could be.  I would like to try this place again (like I said, pretty good food), but I would love to be able to get in and out in under an hour, as opposed to the hour and a half we experienced.
author: Lynnie P.

description: GREAT FOOD FOR GREAT PRICES!!  The only downfall is if you get a seat downstairs, it can sometimes smell like toilet.
author: Leisheung P.

description: This is a good chinese restaurant near the financial district...I still come here once in a while with co-workers for lunch and the food is still good, but it's had better times (when my dad used to own it =P ). They serve your typical chinese dishes...but i usually order stuff that's off the menu.
author: meL Z.

description: Went there for lunch today, can't go wrong with $5.75 lunch specials. I had the broccoli, shrimp & scallops which came with a large portion of steamed rice, tea, and hot an sour soup.  The food was pretty good..but didn't blow me away.  Service was quick and the staff was friendly.
author: Tania J.

description: yes its cheap and quick but the MSG was enough to make any return visit a moot point. bleech
author: Tripp S.

description: Decent food, pretty good price...  Nothing really special about this place.
author: Gigi T.

description: Came here for lunch and ordered the seafood chow mein and dry beef chow fun. Portions were small as hell and it was so greasy. Other than that, it was typical Chinese food. Nothing special and prices were okay. Im not coming back for lunch unless I get the lunch specials.
author: SF N.
